item.description:
Malle Getallen (Crazy Numbers) is a Quartett with math exercises. The game is played with deck of cards, which is divided into sets of four cards, each with its own symbol. On each card, there is a math exercise (add or substract from 0 to 20).

Each player starts the game with six cards. On his turn, a player may ask another player for a card with a specific symbol. If that player has that card, he reads the exercise out load. If the asking player gives the correct answer, he gains the card, and gets to go again. If he does not give the correct answer, or if the other player does not have the card that was asked for, the asking player gains the card from the deck, and his turn ends.

When a player has collected a complete set of four cards, he sets them aside and gains one point. The game ends when all sets have been set aside; the player with the most points wins the game.

With this Dutch game you practice to read the digital and the analog clock.

The game has two different sides:
- If you play with the domino side, is about matching the same times on top of each other. Thus, one quarter past 9 fits with 9.15 or with the correct drawing of the clock.

- If you play with the other side, you may submit series, add cards for other players, or even steal cards from other players!
You can play this by ranking the times by earlier - later!

Kaboom! is a card game for two to five players. The objective of this game is to, well…blow stuff up. You are under attack by well-armed and not-so-polite enemies. You can erect walls to protect yourself, and lob all kinds of incendiary devices at your enemies. But they will be doing the same to you. If they destroy all of your walls and take you out, then it’s Kaboom! You get the picture.

Game play is very simple. Players have a hand of cards that are made up of four different types that can be used to attack their opponents and defend against incoming attacks. As the game progresses, the players will have their protective walls slowly whittled down to nothing. This leaves them exposed and the next attack from any opponent that cannot be blocked immediately eliminates the player from winning the game, but does not remove them from the game. As soon as this happens, the endgame is triggered and the Endgame cards come into play. The Endgame cards are special cards that keep eliminated players in the game to hinder all those who are still in the running to win the game.

The game ends when there is only one player left who has not been eliminated. This player, being the only one to survive the battle, is automatically the winner.

Economic game in which players play either company, bank or government. A player puts down a package of asset and debt cards - but only assets are face-up. The next player can either accept the package, add cards and pass it on, or doubt that the assets cover the debt cards. The wronged player gets permanent debts, and at the end of the game, the player with the lowest debts wins. 
Each player also has a rating that influences his/her hand cards, so the challenge is not entirely an uninformed decision.

This treasure hunt is played on a spiral board; there is a treasure in the middle that players are trying to reach. Each player is secretly assigned the color of one of the pawns, and each player gets three cards. 
The active player rolls two dice and multiplies the result with the number of one of the cards in his/her hands to move the pawn of the same color (as the card) the corresponding number of fields. If the pawn lands on a spiral, it changes positions with another pawn; if it lands on a feather, it can move the double distance. 
When the first pawn reaches the center field, the secret colors are revealed, and the player who has the same color as the winning pawn wins the game.

This is a redo of the old classic, available as a limited edition only through the National World War II Museum in New Orleans, LA. The properties become famous land and sea battles in both the ETO and PTO, ending in VE Day and VJ Day. There are six new tokens - B-17 Bomber, combat boots, cathedral radio, LCVP, Sherman tank and American combat helmet. Chance and Community Chest turn into Allies and Home Front. Houses turn into camps and hotels turn into headquarters.

"This game was designed to be fun, but also to teach important principles about Christian Stewardship. The game emphasizes that being a good steward is a way of life, and that it is about the daily decisions we make in the use of out time, talent and treasure." (From the teacher's packet included with the game.)

Players roll a die to move around the board, reading aloud from one of four types of cards that match the square they landed on, then acting out what the card says to do. If the player lands on a "Word on Stewardship" space, they draw a card from that stack and have thirty seconds to look up the Bible verse listed on it. (Bible and timer are NOT included in the game pieces.) If the player cannot find the verse in time, they move backwards on the board. If they do find the verse, play halts until the player reads the verse aloud.

Play continues until one player lands on the "Well done good and Faithful Steward" by exact roll. This person is the winner.

Steel Towers is a game of city building, monster attacks, and high profits! After years of relentless attacks by aliens, gorillas, and monsters, Scraper City has finally banished these nuisances to a holding facility in the next state, where they are controlled by electronic collars. Downtown is ready to grow again! As real estate moguls in this once-again booming city, players compete to make the most money by building Skyscrapers to attract rent-paying tenants.

However, the Skyscrapers that make the most money are in the best Neighborhoods. Players hold cards which give them the right to build Skyscrapers along specific streets, while attracting valuable Businesses, knocking down unsightly Abandoned Buildings, and cleaning up Junkyards. However, the moguls try to foil each other by taking control of Mutant Monsters, Giant Gorillas, or Alien Attacks, making construction in Scraper City perilous at best.

The novel game mechanic for determining revenue from Skyscrapers at the end of each turn means that the most thoughtful strategy will prevail! The winning mogul is the one with the most money after ten years (turns) of building and collecting rent. Steel Towers is a unique game with easy-to-learn rules, but deep strategy.

Terra is new semi-cooperative board game from Touko Tahkokallio. 
The game is targeted to school classes and the theme is environmental. In the game players are collectively trying to save the world from the environmental catastrophes. Players win or lose the game collectively, but still you can count who's got the most successful country.

In Terra you play five rounds and every player has one turn in every round. Every player represents a country and all players together represent the international community. 
1. At the start of the round you remove old development tiles and turn over six new development tiles. 
2. Then first player starts his turn. On his turn player can do next actions as many times as he can afford in free order:
-Buy one development tile.
-Activate development tile with his/her worker.
-Donate money to planetary fund to avoid catastrophes.
-Trade with other players (one on one)
-Remove catastrophe markers (with two money)
After player has made as many actions as she/he wishes, it's next players turn. 
3. After every player has had turn, then global warming kicks in. First you remove two carbon cubes from the atmosphere and then temperature marker goes up as many places as there is carbon cubes left. (New carbon cubes emerge when you burn coal in power plants.)
4. And then environmental catastrophes kick in. The temperature track tells you how many catastrophe cards you turn over. Now the chairman of the international community (i.e. starting player of this round) decides how to use planetary funds to overcome catastrophes. If he/she can't defeat catastrophes they will hit every player.
5. At the end of the round every country has to feed its workers and produce needed energy. Player loses points and workers if she/he can't. And finally chairman of the international community marker goes to next player.

During the game you get points from some of the development tiles (cities, schools, laboratories) and at the end of the game you get points from workers, money and all your development tiles. Catastrophes make you lose money when they happen and points at the end.

To succeed you collectively most have more than 50 points (minimum 0, maximum 100). If the game is played in the classroom with many copies, then you can also see which group got the best overall score.

The main part of the game are 30 "quotes" of 20 different philosophers. Each player gets on philosopher at random at the start.

Each round the starting player selects one of his quotes read it aloud. The every other player "answers" with one of his philosopher's quote. At the and of the round each player has three votes "0", "1" and "2" and has to vote for one othewr player.

Points are awarded for 3 differnt categories: Sum of the votes, Wininng a round, losing a round.

Whoever "wins" the first of the three 36 point in total or 5 wins or 5 losses (cynics-score), wins the game.

From the Passport Instructions to the "Original" World Rummy by Adell:

"Original" World Rummy is a game designed to combine the timeless appeal of playing cards with the impact of Backgammon and the strategy of chess.

Instructions are printed in 26 languages for the enjoyment of your family and friends around the world. Besides the languages listed in this entry, the rules are also printed in Farsi (Persian) and Swahili.

There are 106 tiles (each measuring 27 mm x 33 mm) used in the game. There are 2 jokers and 104 numbered tiles. The numbered tiles are in four colors: Black, Red, Blue and Yellow. Think of these as card suits. Each color consists of 13 "ranks" (numbered 1 to 13) and there are 2 sets of 1-13 in each color.

The tiles are mixed up and placed face down in the middle of the table. Each player draws one and the player drawing the lowest number goes first. 14 tiles are drawn by each player into their rack.

Objective: The first player to play out all their tiles in their rack wins the hand. The winner scores the tile points that are left in their opponent's racks. First player to get 500 points is the winner.

A player's turn begins with drawing a tile. Players lay down melds of 3 or more tiles ("sets" of the same rank or "runs" (consecutive ranks in the same color)). Once each player has laid down 1 meld, they can play on the melds of other players. If the player can't play on their own or another person's meld, they must pass. There's a sand timer, so player's lose their turn if they spend too much time analyzing their options.

Splitting runs and sets:
As an example, if you have a Black 7 tile, you can split a Black run 9-8-7-6-5 into 2 runs - Black 5-6-7 and Black 7-8-9. If you have a Red 8-9, you can split 4-10's (Red, Black, Blue, Blue) into run Red 8-9-10 and set of 3-10's (Black, Blue, Blue).

The Jokers have some restrictions on their use, but they can be powerful options for a player's strategies. If you have the right tile, you can play it to replace a Joker, but then you must play the Joker right away; you cannot place it back in your rack.

Besides the tiles, the game comes with 4 tile racks (some assembly required) and 2 sand timers.

Prepare for invasion! Robotech RPG Tactics is a tactical miniatures game set in the Robotech universe. While the 1/285th scale game pieces can be used as a companion to the Robotech RPG, the game system is designed to be played as a tabletop miniatures game. Players build armies of multiple squadrons of mecha to fight it out in scenario-driven, objective-based game play. Take command of the fighting forces of the United Earth Defense Force (UEDF) valiantly defending Earth from alien annihilation – or lead the massive clone armies of the Zentraedi Armada to recover an alien artifact of immense power and enslave humankind. Depending on the faction, and their choice of mecha, a player's army may include anywhere from two game pieces to as many as you desire! The rules are scalable from small skirmishes to mass combat with hundreds per side.

Robotech RPG Tactics uses a dynamic turn system. Players trade off activating squadrons during each turn, ensuring that a player never has to sit and wait while his opponent moves and attacks with his entire army. By using alternating activation of squadrons, the game's action unfolds at a fast and furious pace, allowing large scale battles to be easily carried out in a single evening. Each player receives a number of Command Points each turn based on the number of mecha they have on the field, and the quality of their officers. Command Points are spent throughout the turn on maneuvers such as boosted movement, devastating weapon salvos, breakneck dodging counterattacks, and potent special abilities.

The wide variety of mecha in the boxed game bring to bear the myriad and awesome weapon systems from the Robotech universe to lay waste to your foes. Even the battlefield itself can alter over the course of the game as buildings are leveled by destruction unleashed during the battle.

item.description:
In Space Relics, each player is a space pirate racing against the others to get the most items and most valuable artifacts out of an intergalactic museum.

The game board has a grid for the platform tiles that players will need to move around in order to reach the fixed gallery tiles where the items and artifacts can be found. The platform and galleries (except for the center gallery tile) are set up randomly each game.

Players start the game with 12 action points to use for movement and relocating tiles. However, the action points are reduced by 1 each round to simulate the space suits running out of air and power.

Items and artifacts are randomly drawn from two decks of cards. However, the primary artifact, The Heart of Sol, is always in the center of the board.

Art by Steve Thomas (www.stevethomasart.com)

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Star Trek: Attack Wing is a tactical space combat miniatures game, featuring pre-painted ships from the Star Trek Universe.

By using the FlightPath maneuver system* (licensed from Fantasy Flight Games), players engage in exploration and combat, traversing sprawling Star Trek space maps made available via an in-store Organized Play program. As commander, players have the ability to customize, upgrade, and assign famous crewmembers to their fleets, which feature ships from the series' prominent empires and forces as well as special stats and abilities, and unique maneuvers on separate Combat Dials.

Star Trek: Attack Wing is a standalone game which uses the core rule set of FFGs' FlightPath game system with a Star Trek twist, but is not compatible with other FlightPath games from FFG. The FlightPath maneuver system used in Star Trek: Attack Wing is based on the original game design by Jason Little.

item.description:
You will manage and guide the migration of five species of birds. However, not every specie has the same flight habits flight and do not travel the same distance. You will therefore have to adaptat your strategy and to play the right cards at the right time, pay attention to obstacles, and keep an eye on the opponent's game ...

Each player must manage migration up to 5 birds (Brant, Black Kite, Black-winged Stilt, European Bee-eater and teal) to send them to the destination. Players will straight ahead at maximum 4 colonies simultaneously. A turn begins and ends with still 3 cards in hand, and each turn, each player may put a card in the game to start a colony or complete one (provided that the number of birds on the card is equal or lower than the previous). On the cards are the target for each type of bird (a number of cards of this type of bird), the distribution of the number of birds for each type of bird and if it is migrant birds day only, night only, or day and night. Because the maps corresponding to phases of flight day will be put face up, face down but those night! Rather than place a card, the player can if desired separate colony in two of his game, and reassociate into two colonies.
At the end of his turn, a player must discard a card from his hand and complement 3 by drawing cards.

Once a player has reached the goal of a specie (a number of cards depending on the type of bird), he puts his colony in a heap next to his game and can not migrate these birds . The last card that will put equal to the number of points that this bird brings him. The opponent may still him in his game to migrate this type of bird.

Players will also play cards "Dangers" (Hunter day, night light pollution and destruction of natural day and night), which can steal a card from an opponent among current flight phases or among birds which have reached their destination.

The game ends when one of the two players that get the fifth type of bird, the two players combined. The winner is whoever has the most points (numbers of birds arrive at their destination for every type of bird).

item.description:
Merlin stole a spellbook to his father then was captured by the witch. His friends, Viviane, Lancelot, Guinevere and Arthur went looking for him and were able to deliver him ...
Remains to reach the village of Broceliande to give the spellbook back to its owner but they are pursued by the monstrous cat Morpnage ...

In this game, players join forces to lead all the characters to the village before being caught by the cat.
Players will send (literally) spells on the track
according to a precise technique indicated by a special dice.

According to the case indicated by the spell, players will advance a character, use a secret passage, give a character invisibility or reverse the hourglass. But, these spells can also have side effects that will waste precious time to players.

The cat wall advance whenever the hourglass will have elapsed (ie once per minute)or whenever and 3 spells have been sent off to the track spells. If the cat catch up a character on the board he or she will be eaten.

item.description:
You are a gang leader and your aim is to become the Patron of the city. In order to do this, you will recruit and use your henchmen to manage traffic and take control of the neighborhoods, in short, anything that will get you up into the Mob.

Gangs City is based on a mechanism of laydown tiles where the characters perform different actions (fight, recruitment or traffic) according to the direction of their tile and where their location. During a turn, you place your characters, one by one, trying to assess the tactics your opponents to not let yourself overwhelmed by the other gangs.

item.description:
Objective: be the first leading all (3) of your meeples home
 - moving by turns -
a 'Pachisi'-variant

Each player has a set of 3 meeples that start in his/her corner of the board. The goal is to move the meeples around the board back to the "home" section (=start). Movement is controlled by dice. All players move around the same board, so they may throw out others meeples. Thrown ones are returned to their player's corner and must start again. The winner is the first player to move all meeples "home". 
The major difference is located as red square (8 spaces) in the middle of the board, which must passed 4 times. It becomes a bottleneck, because only one meeple may move into (next step out of) it. During this period it can be thrown out easily.

item.description:
In about all Bible trivia games, players are required to do memory dumps from their mind. In Find It! it is different. In Find It! it is different. In the game, players are allowed to look through a Bible they have, to find the answers.

Each turn, a player takes the role of a moderator, and asks a question. Players would then rush to try to find the answer in the Bible. First player to find the answer would score points.

Player to first reach a target score, or have high score after a set amount of time wins the game. The game can vary difficulty by given clues as to Old or New Testament, book, and also chapter. Players can also play with either preset cards, or have players create questions on the fly.

2 different games with a similar approach: build your individual course, play it and create a new one... 
Objective: 
score as many points as possible by pushing the ball with a swinging hammer into target zone; repeat it 4 x and add results; if your ball leaves the course or if you don't master the obstacle ==> penalty
You can modify course and target zone up to 16 different challenges

of Shot & Blade is a boardgame of action, magic and high adventure set in the unique fantasy world of Edath where non-combat skills are as influential as combat in surviving a wild and broken world. The game allows for a variety of simple adventures to be played – skirmishes, quests, hunts, investigations, etc – and in a variety of settings.

Players split into two teams. The Adventurers Team attempt to achieve a final objective and take their squads and champions across three Locations against beasts, ravines, natives and the like, while the Nemesis Team aims to thwart them.

With each encounter, the players draw from their chosen Skills and any support they may get, and opposed players engage in a conflict where their dice rolls are influenced in a back and forth fashion until one player can do no more and so loses that particular contest, suffering the consequences.

By the time the final goal is reached the Adventurers will have succeeded or failed to acquire boons and other bonuses that can aid them in an all or nothing last ditch attempt to succeed in their mission. Adventures can be played stand alone or as part of a series.

item.description:
Walking through the Italian Dolomite mountains you can see special Flowers, Animals, Waterfalls, Canyons and Mountain Tops. The player who visits the most of these and builds their Rifugios (Italian for 'mountain cabin') in strategic spots, is most likely to win the game.

In Rifugio you place hexagonal tiles every turn with just a few simple rules (meadows next to forest, next to rocky areas, which in turn are the only areas allowed to have mountain tops. No rock next to meadows, and no mountain tops next to forest or meadows. A few special tiles have to match their sides exactly.

With your pawn (a backpacking tourist) you move around the placed tiles, visiting those that have special items printed on them (animals, flowers, waterfalls, etc.), and avoiding those with bears. By visiting special places, you collect a victory points card (usually 2 points) for that special place (for a bear however, you get -3 points). There are three items in each category, and collecting the full set earns you a bonus of 5 points.

Each turn you have two free actions available, to either move, or place a Rifugio (a mountian cabin). Each time an opponent visits a tile with your Rifugio, you get a card with 2 victory points, but they to rest (which is getting a card with an extra action they can use at any time convenient).

Game ends when all tiles have been placed, and whoever gathered the most points in collecting those cards wins.

item.description:
A card/party game for 2-5+ people, played while watching any horror movie.

Players use Plot cards that coincide with actions on the screen to earn points, and Curse cards to force their opponents to reenact scenes or otherwise interact with the movie.

Act as a stay at home mom trying to clean the house. Each player moves through their own house (a play mat) trying to clean. The first player with a clean house wins. The trouble is that there is a child in each house controlled by the game. The child moves through the house playing with toys and making a mess.

A child with no toys will help clean up but it is risky to try to keep they toys from the child because the mom only has two hands to work with. The child cannot go into mom's room or the garage so toys can be stored there but it takes time to move.

This game is part strategy and part luck.

Each player acts as a friend, relative, or associate of one of the greatest heroes in the land. The characters have all been kidnapped by the Jagjit, the Dark King of Aloion, and taken to a place known only as the Haunted Dungeon to be used as sacrifices. Jagjit hopes to bring about the return of Artamog the Butcher, an ancient dark god. Artamog the Butcher once ruled over all the world before Rachna, the Goddess of Creation, sealed Artamog and his children away from the world.
The characters must rescue themselves from the Haunted Dungeon. If the characters die while within the confines of the dungeon, Artamog will return to the world. If even one character escapes alive, the world will be safe, for now.
This is a tile based fantasy dungeon crawl. The goal is to fight through the rooms, collect items for defense, find and defeat the dungeon boss (a powerful enemy guarding the only exit), and escape.
As a twist, dead characters become ghosts and are still capable of influencing the game.

Build defenses and collect parts so you can turn your city into a giant flying machine before a rampaging mechanical hoard destroys the land.

Roll dice each round to determine if you get defenses, flying machine components, or agents capable of sabotage. Work with or against neighboring cities. Each round the mechanical hoard will attack random parts of the city. The first city in the air wins.

Each player controls an air fleet and engage in a battle. Each side has a city, up to 2 airships, and up to 4 fighters. Once a player's city is destroyed, they are out of the game. At the end of each round, the wind pushes the fleet, complicating the strategy of troop deployment.
As fighters and airships are destroyed, new ones can be launched by sacrificing the ability to attack. Ships can crash into each other and mountains causing damage.

A children's clone of Monopoly where the object is to be the player with the most Goosebumps (money) at the end of the game. The game ends when any player owes more Goosebumps than he or she can play. Small plastic faces with "hair" standing on end and mouth in a "scream" position are used to identify the owener of each property who also has a deed to the property.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
Using individually rated player cards and dice "Bones" players select from 10 run or 6 pass plays on offense, and 12 defenses to play a simple to learn, yet very detailed game of football. Football Bones builds off the original Statis Pro model by Jim Barnes and updates to a Base-10 system allowing for greater variability and realism in the results. Advanced statistics previously unavailable have allowed us to come up with the most accurate player cards and that translates to accurate play on the field!

Play by Play has been studied and every ball handler in the game now more accurately reflects on-field performance. 3 yards and a cloud of dust, yup we have that!

One of the beauties of the original Statis Pro system was and is the simplicity. Cover 2, Cover 3 it’s in there, Wildcat got it!, 6 Offensive lineman got it!, 3 Tight Ends got it! More plays and strategies, weather rules, a new model for quarterbacks and ball handlers. Solo, league, and replay tested…… All the fun and excitement of the original Statis Pro game is there and we’ve added so much more……

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

Loosely translated from the publisher's site:
Game about the history of Portugal and the Portuguese identity.

More than a game, the Quinto Império (translated as Fifth Empire) is a journey through history and the identity of a people with timeless traditions.

Based on the 5th and 6th grade curriculum, the game is an extraordinary way of remembering the Portuguese origins.

Since the birth of the Kingdom of Portugal the kings always sought to expand the national territory.

Now, it's up to the player of playing a Portuguese historic character, and recreate the great voyages and adventures of Prince Henrique the Navigator, Vasco da Gama, Afonso de Alburquerque or other fearless Portuguese sailor.

Discover and (re)invent the Fifth Empire of Father António Vieira and Fernando Pessoa.

The destiny of the empire is in your hands.

Game play:
The purpose of the game is to get more points than the other player or get the starting objectives accomplished

Through the buying of national monuments with the trade goods acquired in trade posts or with the 14 resources, or the 9 Padrões (stone pillars with the Portuguese coat of arms used to mark the claim of land during the Portuguese age of discovery) that you can get by answering right to the questions.

item.description:
The setting is a horror convention. Your goal is to get close enough to nab the guest of honor—Desiré Delamorte, your dream girl—before the convention attendees discover that you're not just in costume. At game's end, one monster's going to get mobbed by con-goers. And one just might get away with the girl.
 Each deck contains 56 cards--that's four monster suits and a couple of extra-special cards. Each suit includes the monster itself, ten convention attendee cards, one Desiré Delamort card, and one Flash Armstrong card (her sports star boyfriend).

The idea is to capture as many Desiré Delamort cards as possible, while avoiding attendees of your own suit. You especially want to avoid the Flash Armstrong card; he riles up any suspicious attendees.

Fortunately, each monster has a special ability: Dracula's mesmeric gaze, Mummy's whirlwind, Werewolf's shape change, and Frankenstein's Monster's sheer strength, for example.

Add suits for monsters from the other decks in the series (Return of Monster Con, Son of Monster Con, and Monster Con: Cthulhu Pack), and you can play with as many as sixteen players! Each game also contains a pair of non-suited cards—from "Sleeping in the Movie Room" to "Necronomicon"—to add their own twists to play.

The 4 decks include the original with Dracula, the Mummy, Frankie, and the Werewolf; the Return of Monster Con with the Amorphous Blob, Alien Changeling, Invisible Man, and Swampy; Son of Monster Con with the Bride of Frankenstein, Undertaker, Phantom of the Opera, and Ghost of Room 13, and; the Cthulhu Pack with the Cthulhu Cultist, Innsmuoth Cousin, Pickman's Apprentice, and Nyarlathotep.

With each deck, you can play with three or four people ages 13 and up. Playing time is about 30-45 minutes.

Guilds of Florence is a worker programming game where every player represents a clan of humble origin that is putting all their savings into improving the status of the clan. In order to do this, they will send their brightest sons as apprentices to some of the guilds of the city in seek of fame and fortune. To facilitate this, they will also marry some of their prettiest daughters to influential members of society in order to gain access to their exclusive guilds.

Game flow:
1. Coming of age: each clan adds a son ready to work and a daughter ready to marry to their resource pool.

2. Getting a job: each clan sends as many sons from the resource pool to find a job as apprentices as they want and can afford. To get a job as an apprentice, you must have influence in that guild, there must be an available apprentice slot (only one per guild every turn) and you must have enough money to pay the admission fee.

Other ways of getting influence in otherwise inaccessible guilds, is by marrying your daughters to one of the meeples already in that guild. By doing so you gain access to that guild as long as that daughter lives or if you have already sons working in that guild.
Some guilds can only be accessed by bribing the master a fixed amount of money.

3. Wedding day: each clan marries as many daughters from the resource pool as they want and can afford. To marry your daughters you need to pay the dowry to the lucky husband-to-be.
When choosing which husband in a guild you would like to marry, your clan needs to have someone (son or daughter) in a guild of the same class as the target one. For example, someone in a minor guild, can only marry someone in a minor guild, whereas someone in a major guild can marry anyone.

4. Pay day: in this phase salaries get paid, products get made and products get exchanged for money.

5. Time goes by: apprentices may become journeymen. Journeymen may become masters or keep improving their skills and maybe get a higher wage. Masters may improve their mastery and gain increased reputation and produce more products. Masters that reached the highest in their career, when time goes by, will sadly pass away. Same applies to their wives, who will also suffer the same fate.

6. Going to the market: each player buys as many products as they want and can afford. They can also exchange certain products for different products as a barter according to the market table. They CANNOT sell products for money; only masters can sell their own products for money.

7. Adjusting turn order: in turn order, and one at a time, players may exchange sets of products for licences (VP). Move the VP tracker for those players accordingly. Once all players have passed in sequence, the new starting player will be the one with the most VP at this point in time.

End of the game and scoring
The game ends when all players run out of meeples as they have all passed away.
The game also ends immediately if after one full turn, none of the guilds have any meeple on them but there are meeples in the clan or resource pools.
The winner is the player with most Victory Points.

Searching for a way to transplant brains we found a new way to have fun. Dare someone to get Brainwashed. Place the Brainwash hat onto your head. Exchange Brain Hand pumps with your opponent, so you are holding the one attached to their hat and they are holding yours. On the count of three start squeezing the Brain Hand Pump using only one hand! Keep pumping the Brain until one of you is Brainwashed! When the brain in fully inflated, this will release the water held in the brain reservoir. The player with the fully inflated brain will be soaked with water. The winner is the first player to fully inflate their opponents brain so that they are Brainwashed!

Let's chase a rat! The objective of the game is to be the first player to stop the rat running. The rat will run in random directions around the room for 20 seconds. Chase the rat around the room and hit the button on its back with your broom. The rat will respond with each correct hit by making a "yip yip" sound. Once you've successfully hit it 4 times, the rat will stop and make a crying sound. But if you don't, the rat will stop and laugh at you!

Presumably, a simple roll and move game, given the times and the type of games that existed in the 1890's.

This 1890 game from McLoughlin Bros. is listed with a picture at Bored Games.

The game is based on a TV show in the 1960's. Players are racing to claim territory in the strip of land between Kansas and the Indian Territory in the old west. There are 23 territories (areas) in the Cimarron Strip which are now open for claiming. Movement is by a spinner. Players start with a stand-up playing piece showing a cowboy and 7(?) claim tokens. The board consists of a map of the 23 areas, the starting area outside the Cimarron Strip, and paths connecting everything. Each area has one red space that the players must land on to claim the area. If 2 players land on the same spot there is a gunfight using a deck of "hit" or "miss" cards.

In Alchemist Academy you play a young and gifted student at Eggelstein Hall known better to the students as Alchemist Academy, a school for the magically gifted. Your grades have slipped. With only a few weeks to go you need to raise your grades and fast! There is only one solution..... if you can’t pass….CAST!

Game Play
Alchemist Academy is a fast, light-hearted card game for 2 to 6 players and is played in 30 to 60 minutes. Alchemist Academy is a hand management card game relying on 2 decks of cards, a Spell Deck and Shop Deck.

The game includes 23 different spells within the spell deck, which consists of 64 cards in total. Along with 6 different component cards which are required in different variations when casting a spell, this deck consists of 120 cards in total.

Each class (round) players attempts to cast spells on each other and themselves to increase their grade (score). Each of these spells require the correct components in order to cast it. These components are drawn from the Shop Deck.

Some spells are quick and easy to cast and only require 1 or 2 common components to be cast, however these only give the caster a small bonus. Other spells require rare or unique items to be cast and while this might take longer to obtain the right components, the resulting spell is far more powerful.

If the spell is successfully cast, there will be some sort of effect and the player who cast the spell gains points.

item.description:
It is the eve of Carnivale on the magical Victorian isle of Ludobel, and you are all invited to the fantastical festivities!

In the card game Belle of the Ball, players take on the roles of party hosts, seeking the best mix of guests to make their gala the greatest by the end of the night. In order to ensure that they stay one step ahead of the other hosts, players will have to carefully watch the growing line of guests at the door, inviting those in that seem to share passions with partygoers already inside, all the while handing out their precious stash of Regrets to those who should seek refuge elsewhere. Of course, other hosts may find it advantageous to invite a rejected guest inside just to collect their accumulated Regrets for later use.

Hosts may also choose to ignore the competition for guests and instead try to earn the favor of the Belle of the Ball herself, whose charms can make or break any party.

item.description:
It's a time of regrowth in the old urban center, and the hippest and best beer crafters have gathered both hops and hopes in building the best brewery in the city. It won't be an easy task, as players compete for precious resources such as malt, yeast, fruit and spices in the local markets, all while managing and optimizing their growing bottling empires.

In Brew Crafters, players assume management of a local craft brewery, working hard to manage resources, use their workers wisely, and develop their brewing line to create the best local brews. Brew Crafters honors the tradition of classic Eurogames such as Agricola and Puerto Rico, but at its heart beats a unique brewery processing system that must be constantly improved, monitored, and manned in order to keep the beloved beverages rolling off the line. Each brewery has access to a variety of equipment upgrades, local farms, markets, and a plethora of specialty workers, ensuring a high level of replayability and strategic avenues. In addition, each player is studiously working to be first to develop several rotating gold-label specialty recipes that will earn them extra points and prestige at the end of year three when the best local brewer will be honored.

item.description:
VivaJava: The Coffee Game: The Dice Game – or, more simply, VivaJava Dice – is the successor to the well-received 2012 release of VivaJava: The Coffee Game. As in its predecessor, players of VivaJava Dice take on the roles of employees at the VivaJava CoffeeCo., scouring the globe for the best beans to keep the company on top while keeping themselves one step ahead of the rest of the executives.

Also as in VivaJava, VivaJava Dice has players making the crucial decision between blending beans and research, but with a quick, new twist. Players must now use the dice in their pool to blend – using the beans to create a best-seller for quick points, then deciding whether to press their luck in subsequent rounds for bigger points but fewer dice as the blends degrade – or to research, which involves using their valuable beans to gain an ever-changing variety of dice-manipulating abilities, new ways to score, and paths that lead to aiding a competitor for a later payoff or hindering that competitor for immediate gratification. VivaJava Dice also offers a unique system of cooperative dice-rolling that can help you rise to the top, but at the price of someone else riding your coattails.

With an astounding mix of plug-and-play research abilities, subtle social play in semi-cooperative mode, and the chance to hog all the glory and blend the best for yourself, VivaJava Dice is all about choice, making each game fast and furiously different.

item.description:
"When two wireheads test their skills against eachother several factors decides the outcome; the ability to learn and adapt fast to changes, flexibility in strategy and tactics when necessary, master of both attack and defense, courage to try the unknown and wits to outsmart the other combatant." 
- Enigma, also known as TripWire (Legendary Y-Gen wirehead)

Wireheads is a two-player deck building game set in a cyberspace environment. Players takes the role of a wirehead. Each character in the game has different strengths and abilities. Wireheads connect to the virtual world through an interface which may be upgraded or loaded with powerful software to be better prepared for the unknown. In the virtual world they fight for power and glory.

Choose a set of cards that fits your strategy. A typical round of Wireheads consists of a Draw phase followed by the action phase where players use enhancements, upload softwares and sabotage for the opponent in order to gain advantage. New cards are learned from the source and added to your deck. Cards on hand are both effect, software and power to learn new. All cards are freely played from hand without cost. However, stored software and hardware upgrades pay upkeep.

Strike at your opponents interface, exhaust their deck or archive, negate cards on hand. Everything is allowed in order to defeat your opponent.

Every game will differ from the other due to the fact that different cards are available and of those you choose only the cards that fit to the situation and strategy.

Strap up and connect, Wirehead.

"No strategy is good but the strategy to observe, adapt and act faster than your enemy."

The game components:
216 Cards (36 different cards with 6 cards each)
16 Power cards

A modern twist on the traditional game of Memory. THere are 24 tiles featuring 12 pairs. The pairs are represented by appropriate sounds on the electric gadget (who is called Marvin the Mouse).

The tiles are placed face down on the table and shuffled around. In a turn, a player presses the Green Arrow button on Marvin and a random sound will be heard. Now the player must look for the pair related to that sound. If successful, the player keeps the pair and presses the blue button on Marvin so that the same sound will not feature any more in the current game.

The 12 sounds are:
Cat, Thunderstorm, Road-Drill, Church Bell, Dog, Children, Wind, Birds singing, Rain, Car-Horn, Barrel Organ and Footsteps.

The winner is the player with the most tiles after all the tiles have been matched.

A fast paced game where you have to be really quick if you want to be the last penguin standing. In this fast paced game of penguin tug-o-war, each player spins his snowball as fast as possible until all of your opponent's penguins slide out of the tray.

A crisis has occurred in the most unlikely of places: the bathroom!! So gear up and get ready to capture the ugly creatures that have invaded the bathroom form underneath the toilet. Flush is a fast paced game where players race against the clock to get all their creatures into the toilet before it flushes and they get wet. Now you can play with the toilet water!

The first player starts the game by lifting the toilet lid, this will start the game and creatures will start popping out so you can capture them. Once the toilet starts to spin, scattering creatures everywhere, all players compete at the same time by attempting to capture the creatures of their headband color with the magnetic plunger--no hands allowed! Once you have shown your skill by capturing one of the creatures with the plunger attached to your headband you need to send the creature back into the toilet. Remove the creature from the plunger(now you can use your hands) and use the Flipper located on the game base that matches your headband color to flip the creature into the toilet. You need to work fast to get as many of your creatures into the toilet before the toilet flushes and sprays water into your face. Be brave and keep competing to capture the most creatures you can during the last 30 seconds of the game while the water is spraying. When the toilet stops spinning the game is over (approx. 3 minutes). This is the most fun you will ever have with a toilet. The player with the most of their colored creatures in the toilet will be the winner!

Contents:

Game base
Water basin insert
Smiling toilet timer
4 2-piece magnetic headband plungers
24 magnetic "little creatures"

Two teams take turns guessing the identity of the character on the WHO card by asking a yes/no question. Each team only gets five guesses per turn. If guessed, the team now tries to get the WHAT part of the card. Special mystery character cards are included to increase the difficulty. The first team to identify both WHO and WHAT get the character card, and if they get eight they win the game.

This is a rule set of aerial combat set in WW2, Dynamic cartoon style aircraft capture the prominent features of the real planes. Though the aircraft are comic book drawn the maneuvers and abilities are based on reported aircraft performance both anecdotal and charted.

During a game players control from 2 to 12 aircraft by selecting an maneuver on their aircraft information cards, using a dry erase marker. the considerations in selecting a maneuver gaining advantage on the enemy position, and altitude, The maneuvers are then translated into the models movement on the table via a single maneuver template. various speeds of flight are handled in what maneuvers are available to a given aircraft. After moving, aircraft have opportunity to fire at valid targets. Fire combat uses a simple dice system and each craft has its own damage chart encompassing it's special strengths and weaknesses.

The game design features an uncluttered tabletop, squadron building, and aerial terrain and built in altitude rules. Basic and advanced rules allow you to choose what level of detail you prefer.
 Scenarios including ground attack, bomber interception, meeting engagements and more. Each with their own criteria for victory: every thing from hit the target hard and get away, to total control of the skies, to protect your valuable bombers or airbase.

The rules are now available via War game vault, and include elevated paper counters to represent the aircraft models.

Objective: be the first reaching target space (50)
 - moving by turns - 
simple 'Roll & Move' game; ending on a coloured (red/yellow) space follow instructions glued on lid inside. A '6' allows you another roll/move.

Dibdib is a party game for 3-6 players. This game includes two cloth bags, round wooden discs and cardboard heart markers. Each player takes two heart markers. The wooden discs are put into one of the bags and the other bag is left empty.

The first player reaches into the bag with the discs and grabs any number of discs and places them into the second bag. The first player then offers both bags to one of the other players. The second player then has a choice. Either take both bags or take only the second bag. If the second player takes both bags, that player will repeat the steps that the first player took. If the second player takes only the second bag, then the contents of both bags are revealed. The first player counts the discs in the first bag and the second player counts the discs in the second bag. The person with the most discs wins. The loser flips one of his heart markers to the broken-hearted side.

This process is repeated until a player has turned both of his heart tokens to the broken-hearted side.

While at first glance nothing more than a deck of vampire-themed playing cards, Succubus: The Reborn is a new take on a classic game tool: cards. Each card bears a symbol – Rock, Paper, Scissors, Bomb – that makes the deck ideal for fans of Live Action Role Playing (as they often need some randomizing element during play).

What's more, each card contains one or more unique (and sometimes hidden) symbols, which allows the deck to be used for Succubus: The Reborn, the first title in the Party Poker RPG line of games which is playable by 8-90 players (with one deck needed for each ten players). One player serves as the Dealer, who oversees gameplay and leads others in what to do; everyone else is divided as evenly as possible into four teams, the teams being vampires who are members of four great Lineages represented by the four card suits:


 Diamonds – The Marquisi (The Elite Ones) blend in among mortals that they might trade in money, power, and control, all while clinging to an old world sense of protocol and social decorum.



 Hearts – The Copeadora (The Beautiful Ones) are universally insane, but also very beautiful – a benefit which they utilize in order to slake their unholy thirsts at the necks of beautiful socialites and wealthy benefactors.



 Clubs – The Bas-Bazouk (The Outlaws) are the enforcers, criminals, anarchists, and street-toughs of the Vampire world, plying their wits and their supernatural strength to devastating effect in combat.



 Spades – Unlike other Vampires, the Profugos (The Forlorn) do not possess a soul; they are therefore cursed with deep, soulless, black eyes, and are prone to acts of immorality and depravity.


Succubus: The Reborn is played over three acts, and in each act, players try to improve their hand of cards to create the best poker hand. In the first round players can trade however they wish amongst each other as long as each player always has five cards; if a player manages to trade away a joker, that player takes a card at random from the other person's hand instead of any card agreed upon. When the Dealer calls time, the player on each team with the highest card in that team's suit is the Captain, and all the Captains then compete in a single poker hand with the cards they hold, trying to win chips in the process.

From the second act on, players can trade cards with the Dealer for the cost of one chip, taking a random card from what remains in the deck. To trade cards in the second act, you trade in the same manner as the first act or you challenge another player, paying them a chip to do. In a challenge, each player chooses and reveals a card from his hand, with scissors beating bomb, which beats rock, and so on. The winner of the challenge decides whether or not to trade. For the third act, you can trade only with your teammates. After the second and third acts, each team Captain again competes in a poker hand, with the winner of the third such hand winning the entire game and bringing glory to his team.

Succubus: The Reborn includes a number of advanced rules that add quests, shadow symbols that allow for better trades with the dealer, character sheets that add special powers to the game, and more.

Much the same as Top Trumps. However, the cards are much larger (8.8cm x 14.5cm) and each card has 3 categories and a further 3 sub-categories.

Elder Earth set:
Categories (Sub-categories) - Physical (Strength, Skill, Stamina), Material (Armour, Mobility, Weapons) & Magical (Power, Force, Fearfactor)
Robo Legion set:
Categories (Sub-categories) - Mechanics (Fire Power, Forceshields, Armour), Capability (Speed, Mobility, Range) & Intelligence (Controlability, Efficiency, Identification)
Colony Ten set:
Categories (Sub-categories) - Physical (Strength, Skill, Stamina), Material (Armour, Mobility, Weapons) & Magical (Power, Force, Fearfactor)

Object of the Game: The winner is the player with either the most sets of four or the complete pack.
How to play: First decide who will be the dealer, he or she then shuffles the pack and deals it equally between the players. Any spare cards should be placed in the pot. The dealer then picks a card and chooses either a category or sub-category and calls it, the winner is the player with the highest score. he or she then collects that hand and any card in the pot, should there be any. The winning player then continues to play. The play is then taken in turns between the players. 
A variant may be played by the addition of two dice. A player calls a category as with the previous game, then rolls the dice. the dice score is added to the card score to give the players score. The opponent repeats the procedure. The winner is the player with the highest combined score.

item.description: Fishin' Holes is a family-style tile and token game designed for people of all ages. Players take turns casting out to explore tiles, then reeling in by claiming tiles with their tokens. The game has elements of memorization, poker-like bluffing, and some risk taking. The goal is to capture the most fish while staying away from hazards like old tires, boots, or weeds. The game contains 60 pond tiles, wooden player tokens and bonus fish pieces, a score pad and instruction booklet. Rules are simple enough for children as young as age 8, but there is enough strategy to make this enjoyable for adults as well. The game works well for 2-5 players and takes about 30 minutes to play.

Game description from the publisher:

Clockwork Wars is an epic board game of conquest, discovery, and espionage from Eagle-Gryphon Games. In Clockwork Wars, 2-4 players command a unique race of creatures in a tense war set in an alternate universe where magic and steam-era technology collide. Take control of the human "Purebreeds", or one of three hybrid races (Troglodytes, Rhinochs, and Mongrels). Your goal is to vanquish your foes and accumulate the most victory points through seven turns of play. You earn points by fighting for control of territories that contain valuable natural resources. To win these battles, you need manpower gained by seizing villages and developing them into cities. Invest in research and discover astonishing new technologies, like magical Golems, an Analytical Engine, and the wondrous Spire of the Gods. Position your troops, research powerful discoveries, employ espionage, and conquer your enemies to win the game!

Clockwork Wars features:


 A modular map composed of hexagonal tiles and nine territory types (including manufactories, sorcerer's towers, and citadels) that allows for infinite replayability.
 Four different races to choose from, each with its own unique units.
 Hidden and simultaneous unit deployment that provides constant tension.
 Short turns packed with tough decisions.
 Simple, diceless combat resolution.
 A card-based espionage system.
 A unique "technology tree" that is different for every game. Research discoveries in one of three different disciplines: Sorcery, Science, and Religion.
 Light civilization-building mechanisms, as players upgrade villages into cities and research discoveries through three successive, historical ages.
 Rules for both "free-for-all" play, as well as an official 2 vs. 2 team variant

item.description: Typical spin and move children's board game with wooden pieces (red, blue, yellow and green). Game goal is to travel with bicycle from and come back to home first of all. During the travel players should pass Dear Park, Boat House, Pleasant Park, Apple Lane, Hillside Farm etc.

Tactical level wargame based on Japanese anime series Space Battleship Yamato 2199. The game covering space battles for Mars .

Players control star fleet of either the Earth(Terran) or Empire of Gamilas.
The main engine of the game is use chit-pull system. Each turn, players choose to use how many chit for that turn. Each player has four different activation chits(movement, fire, torpedo and repair), but many starships can activate only one to three times in a turn.

The game include five scenarios, two is based on animation story and three is fictional. Winner determined by scenario specific condition.

Hungry frogs are flippin' aross the swamp trying to gobble up the most bugs. But those buzzin' bugs just won't stay put! Using your flippin' skills, and a little luck, you'll need to snatch the next meal before another frog hops along and ruins lunch.

FrogFlip is a 12-card microgame in which players take turns flipping a Frog Disc towards one of four Lily Pad Cards that are spaced evenly across the playing area between two-players. The target Lily Pad Card is determined by the top card in a stack of score cards depicting 1 to 4 bugs. The number of bugs depicted on the top card of the stack represents which Lily Pad Card to aim for (counting that many cards from the active player's side of the table) and the number of points scored if the Frog Disc makes any contact with the target Lily Pad Card. Players keep taking turns flipping the Frog Disc until all of the Bug Score Cards are claimed or one player collects five Bug Score Cards.

Two sets of FrogFlip can be combined for a four-player game.

Publisher Blurb:

Twisted Farkel is sure to excite all Farkel fans and draw even more newcomers to the game. In this exciting version the points one player rolls are not his/hers to keep. The Determinator Die passes the final score for a given turn to players on your left or right. Additionally, unlike regular Farkel, players go out of the game once they reach 10,000 points. The winner is the remaining player with less than 10,000 points. With TWISTED Farkel, passing HIGH scores to your neighbor is the object of the game. When a player FARKELS, (i.e. score no points) their fellow players benefit.

Cthulhu Wars is a strategy boardgame in which the players take the part of alien races and gods taken from the Cthulhu mythos created by H. P. Lovecraft. The game is physically large, and includes sixty-four figurines of the cultists, monsters, aliens, and Great Old Ones that range in height from approximately 20 mm to nearly 180 mm.

The game takes place on a map of Earth. Each player takes the part of one of four factions included in the base game. At the start of a turn, players Gather Power, then, during a series of Action Rounds, they spend this Power to accomplish various tasks, such as recruiting Cultists, moving units, engaging in battle, summoning monsters, building Gates, casting spells, and Awakening their Great Old One. When all players run out of Power, the Action phase ends and the next turn begins. Victory is determined by accumulating points on the Doom Track. The first player to 30 is the lone victor *if* he has unlocked all six of spell books.

Driving the strategy are a player's wish to expand his power base, and his need to accomplish six tasks to acquire his faction's spell books. Each faction has a unique set of monsters, spell books, and special abilities, and has different requirements to acquire its spell books. All factions have multiple strategies open to them.

The base game supports 2-4 players (the map supports 5 players), but with new factions and maps released as expansions it can support up to 8 players.

item.description:
In Fresco, players are master painters, working to restore a fresco in a Renaissance church.

Each round begins with players deciding what time they would like to wake up for the day. The earlier you wake up, the earlier you will be in turn order, and the better options you will be guaranteed to have. Wake up early too often, however, and your apprentices will become unhappy and stop working as efficiently. They would much rather sleep in!

Then, players decide their actions for the turn, deploying their apprentice work force to various tasks. You'll need to buy paint, mix paint, work on painting the fresco, raise money by painting portraits (which you'll need to buy the aforementioned paint!), and perhaps even send your apprentices to the opera in order to increase their happiness. Points are scored mostly by painting the fresco, which requires specific combinations of paints, so you'll need to buy and mix your paints wisely, in addition to beating other players to the paints and frescos you would like to paint.

Fresco: Big Box contains all of the material from the original Fresco game, plus all expansions released through the end of 2012 and the all new 2nd expansion (with modules 8, 9, and 10)! You can play without expansions for a lighter family game, or add in expansions – whether one, two, or all – to vary play and to increase the decision-making and difficulty, resulting in a very flexible game with a high replay value.

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Kaosball is a new kind of fantasy sports game, combining rugby-style passing finesse and first person shooter domination-style scoring. The result is a tense game of skill, bluffing, luck, and lethal brutality like you've never played before!

Brought to you by acclaimed designer Eric M. Lang, Kaosball uses exciting card-based play mechanisms to put players in the role of a coach, managing their unique, game-altering team from scrimmage to sudden death period to outscore their opponents. Players need to balance scoring and killing their opponents, using powerful cheating effects all the while – as long as you have the money to pay off the ref. No two matches will play the same!

Kaosball includes multiple modes of play: traditional head-to-head, partnerships-based alliances, and "Maximum Kaos" three- or four-player mode; 30-60 exhibition games complete with a pregame draft for ringers and team upgrades; and league play with up to eight players and upgrades that stay in place from game to game, creating a unique sense of progression.

item.description:
In Kingdom Builder, the players create their own kingdoms by skillfully building their settlements, aiming to earn the most gold at the end of the game.

Nine different kinds of terrain are on the variable game board, including locations and castles. During his turn, a player plays his terrain card and builds three settlements on three hexes of this kind. If possible, a new settlement must be built next to one of that player’s existing settlements. When building next to a location, the player may seize an extra action tile that he may use from his next turn on. These extra actions allow extraordinary actions such as moving your settlements.

By building next to a castle, the player will earn gold at the end of the game, but the most gold will be earned by meeting the conditions of the three Kingdom Builder cards; these three cards (from a total of ten in the game) specify the conditions that must be met in order to earn the much-desired gold, such as earning gold for your settlements built next to water hexes or having the majority of settlements in a sector of the board.

Each game, players will use a random set of Kingdom Builder cards, special actions, and terrain sectors to build the map!

Kingdom Builder: Big Box includes the first two expansions Kingdom Builder: Nomads, Kingdom Builder: Crossroads as well as two out of three Queenies (Kingdom Builder: Capitol and Kingdom Builder: Caves).

item.description:
Straightforward trivia game by the High Street department store of Marks & Spencer.

Contains 150 questions that relate to Walt Disney characters. Most correct answers after a pre-agreed time, wins.

Note:
Isn't it amazing that a film made before WWII will still be known by any eight year olds who play this game (Snow White for example - even Steamboat Willie gets a question!)?

A card is displayed showing a maze type layout with multiple colored squares. ONLY two of the squares are connected by the maze lines.

Players determine which two squares are connected, then race to duplicate the layout in front of them using various length 4-sided sticks and multicolored cubes.

Players must use the correct color side of the stick and the correct length of stick, plus place them in the right configuration. The cube must be placed in the right location and showing the right color.

First to do so correctly wins the card.

Collect 10 cards and win!

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the Isle of Anglesey, in the UK.

Lowlander is a card-driven solitaire game of fantasy exploration so compact, you can almost take it with you anywhere. Starting from your hut in the wild, your branch out to new frontiers as winter comes along and you need to gather resources in order to survive. But beware, in the vast forests of the realm dark and vicious creatures hide in the shadows.

Select from various scenarios ranging from simple hunts in the wilderlands to defending your home from the forces of the necromancer Yrmgor. No session will be like the other, as the modular gaming board is randomised before each game.

In Lowlander you can take a job in the village, go mining in the mountains, engage in skirmishes with the local fauna or simply collect wood for the winter. As rounds progress, you will move the game's clock, altering it from day to night time, which will impact your encounters in the wild, for it is safer to travel by day.

Lowlander is intended as a budget-game with a rich gaming experience for the true board game enthusiast who needs a solitaire fix and will be released by Q3 2013.
